div1.p: TRINITY HALL CLOSING DAY

TABLET UNVEILED IN MEMORY OF THE
LATE JESSE WILLIAM
LAZEAR, M. D.

Interesting Program of Exercises Carried Out
By the Young Cadets Tuesday Morning.
Honors Conferred and Prizes Distrib-
uted--Rector Smith's Address on the Un-
veiling of the Tablet--The Tablet Inscrip-
tion--Elegant Luncheon Served on the
Lawn at Close of the Exercises--This, the
21st Year, Has Been a Most Successful
One.

Tuesday marked the close of the Trini-
ty Hall Military school. The hall was
beautifully and artistically decorated with
flags, palms and flowers. The most im-
posing scene was the unveiling of a tablet
in honor of the late Jesse William Lazear,
M. D. The platform was occupied by W.
W. Smith, Esq., rector, the Rev. Frank
Steed, of Crafton, U. Grant Smith, com-
mandant, and the class performers. The
exercises were opened with an invocation
by the Rev. Frank Steed. The exercises
throughout were interesting, instructive
and of a high order of excellence, and
well deserved the continued applause
that followed each performer.

The exercises commenced in the school
room, crowded with admiring friends, at
10:30 After the audience being wel-
comed by the rector, the program pro-
ceeded as follows:

Those receiving honorable mention are
W. C. D. Glaser of the fourth form, in
French grammar and history: C. D. Burt-
nett, C. T. Hanna, of the third form, in
geography and L. N. Freland, of the
third form, in Latin; W. B. Matthews
and E. R. Schrwinn of the second form,
in grammar.

In order to obtain first honor one must
have an average of 90 per cent in all stu-
dies and 95 per cent in industry and deco-
rum. For second honor one must have
an average of 85 per cent in all studies
and 90 per cent in industry and decorum.
To receive honorable mention in any one
branch, one must make a grade of 90 or
more.

A number of the boys received prizes
which were distributed by U. Grant
Smith, commandant.
Address of Rector Smith.

On the unveiling of the tablet in mem-
ory of Jesse W. Lazear, M. D, W. W.
Smith, Esq., rector, said:

"It has been a custom, in all ages, to en-
gross in brass or marble, and in the grateful
remembrance of the people, the self-sacrifice
of noble men and women who have given
their fortunes or their lives for the good of
their fellows, and the glory of their coun-
try.

"When the temple of Apollo at Delphi was
to be rebuilt, a noble Athenian family un-
dertook the work, and, instead of using the
common stone of the country called for by
the contract, used Parian marble in its con-
struction. They have their reward in the
admiration of all civilized people since. Mr.
Wood excavating the ruins of the city of
Ephesus, found tablets commemorating the
noble and disinterested deeds of both citizens
and strangers. One tablet was to a corn mer-
chant of Rhodes, who in time of famine, when
food was selling at enormous prices, sent his
corn ships to the city, and sold to the starv-
ing poor, cord at the ordinary prices. He
sent joy to thousands of homes, and strength
and health to many emaciated bodies. The
grateful citizens passed a vote of thanks,
and set up in the temple of Diana a tablet of
marble commemorative of the event.

"When the deep love of Mary, the sister of
Martha, exhibited itself in the breaking of
the box of precious ointment on the head of
our blessed Lord, the sweet odor of which
still fills the world, Jesus said unto the dis-
approving disciples, ‘Verily I say unto you,
wheresoever this gospel shall be preached in
the whole world, there shall also this, that
this woman has done, be told for a memorial
of her.’

"So we, when one of our sons has exhibited
this most God-beloved spirit of self-sacrifice,
think it fitting to erect, in our school room,
this tablet commemorative of his virtue. We
wish others to be taught to love this Christ-
like spirit, and when occasion calls, to be
ready to sacrifice time, fortune and life itself
for the good of their fellow-men.

"Jesse William Lazear was born near the
city of Baltimore in 1866. While being pre-
pared for college at Trinity Hall, he exhibited
those quiet, lovable qualities which so en-
deared him to his associates in after life. He
was pure in mind and healthy in body, and
was a model boy. At Washington and Jef-
ferson college and after at the Johns Hop-
kins University, where he received his
Bachelor's degree, he was a faithful student,
and lived a virtuous life. Three years later
he was graduated and received his Doctor of
Medicine degree from Columbia University,
New York. He was two years House Physi-
cian in the Bellevue hospital, and had charge
of a room for a year, in the Vanderbilt Clinic
in New York city. All athirst for knowledge
and enthusiastic in his profession, he
studied abroad, in Edinburg, Berlin
and Paris, and coming home his merit
was recognized and he was made an
instructor in the medical department
of the Johns Hopkins University--his alma
mater. After the conclusion of the Spanish
war, the government sought him out, made
him assistant surgeon of the army, and sent
him to Cuba on the United States Yellow
Fever commission. The object was to dis-
cover the cause, and find a remedy for that
terrible scourge. They were successful. They
discovered the cause by experimenting on
themselves. Doctor Lazear and one of his
associates died from the poison of the mos-
quitoes used in the experiment. The long
hidden cause was discovered--but at the cost
of two valuable lives. Their names are now
enrolled in ‘the noble army of martyrs.’

“We take great pride in the fact that it was
one of our boys, started on the path of life
from this school room, and this Christian
home, who offered himself on the altar of his
country for the advancement of science, the
glory of God and the good of his fellow men.”

The tablet is inscribed as follows:
IN MEMORY OF
THE VIRTUE AND SELF-SACRIFICE OF
JESSE WILLIAM LAZEAR, M. D.,
OF BALTIMORE, MD.

BORN MAY 20th, 1866.
DIED SEPTEMBER 25th, 1900.

Prepared for college at Trinity Hall, 1880-'84
Graduated at Johns Hopkins University
Medical degree from Columbia University

Instructor in Johns Hopkins University
Assistant Surgeon, United States Army
Died while investigating causes of Yellow
Fever in Cuba

He gave his life to his country for the ad-
vancement of science.
Pro Deo et Patria

The exercises of the day were conclud-
ed with a dumbbell drill and dress parade
which were cleverly executed, after which
an elegant luncheon was served on the
lawn.

This, the twenty-first year of Trinity
Hall school for boys, ended on Tues[day]
June 18. It has been a remarkably s[uc]
cessful year, not only in the high cha[rac]
ter of the boys, but in the progress m[ade]
in their study, Several are prepared for
college and business. Two of the num-
ber for W. and J.--Roy Hardtmayer, of
Allegheny, and O'Neil Kennedy, of Un-
iontown. Others go to Harvard and
Princeton.

The abundant rains of this season have
given the foliage an almost tropical lux-
uriance and the avenues and lawns are
brilliant with masses of roses and syrin-
gas. In fact, this forty acres of park,
with its lofty trees and well kept avenues
and lawns is not excelled for beauty any-
where. Boys brought up amid such sur-
roundings should surely be happy.
